utterances.text: There should be more. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Robert Kosara
utterances.text: Though there were a few journalists here, so I spoke to somebody from 538 and then Jen Christensen is here from Scientific Americans. Right? Yeah. Keep mixing this up. And then, so I know that people are here who are end up paying attention to what's happening here, but there are not a lot of people actually presenting stuff right now. But that might change next year again. And so it's always kind of back and forth.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: So, guys, let's wrap it up. Maybe we want to briefly mention any major trends or new things happened at this, this year. Did you, Robert, did you identify anything that is new or different or trends or whatever you want to say?

utterances.speaker: Robert Kosara
utterances.text: So one thing that I think we were seeing more of is presentation of data. So there's not just so. It used to be that it was all analysis and exploration, and now the idea of presenting data, even though it wasn't directly about journalism, but there were a number of papers this year that talked about how to present data to people, and we mentioned a few of them, the memorability one and a few others. And also just the idea of kind of being closer to what people would do with the data. Like that one about using a study to figure out how to lay out a graph and then use that to build an algorithm. I think that idea of just more presentation oriented visualization is really interesting and that's going to become more important over time. And I think we need to understand how that is different from analysis. And I happen to have some opinions on that. And I actually have a. You wrote something, I have something forthcoming in this video points early next year that's going to talk a bit about that. And there's certainly much more to say about it, but I think that's a really interesting trend and it's actually happening now. So I think we're going to see a lot more of that going forward at CHI's and that viz and Eurovis. So that's really good to see. I really think it's important.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. From my side, I think what I was just saying before I think I've seen a lot of research work done in somewhat in the wild, really trying to work very closely with people who have some kind of problem with data and with presentation. And I think that's another fantastic trend. I think in general, our community is a culture of working with domain experts, and it's very applied. But this year I have the sense that there is even more on that in terms of not just developing something for someone, but studying visualization in the world. Right. And I think that's a really good trend. Joanna, you want to say something?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Well, since this is my first visit, I can't compare to the previous ones, but I'm.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: So, how did you like it?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, it was actually my first real scientific conference, so I'm overwhelmed and there's so much happening and everyone is exhausted. Yeah. Well. But a lot of good takeaways and. Really interesting. I'm happy to be here.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Okay, good. Thanks a lot for coming on the show.

utterances.speaker: Robert Kosara
utterances.text: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Oh, you didn't say anything for.

utterances.text: Oh, yes, of course. Now this is my chance to get even with Andy. I haven't actually, I lost count, but I think I'm now again on par with him. With Andy Kirk. Yeah, that's right. Important to keep track of that and keep score.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Okay. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Robert Kosara
utterances.text: So, yeah, thanks for, for including me here instead of Andy. That's really important for my ego, for sure.

Let your instincts lead the way to create personalized visualizations and dynamic dashboards with Qlik sense. Special edition of data stories directly from the Itripolyvis conference in Chicago.
chapters.headline: Data stories comes directly from the Itripolyvis conference in Chicago

chapters.summary: The IT conference is the premier academic conference in visualization. Robert, Joanna and myself report on the IEEE visconference. We talk about some of the papers and events that we found interesting.
chapters.headline: The IEEE IT conference is the premier academic conference in visualization

chapters.summary: Enrico: Welcome to the special edition data stories special edition from the visualization conference. We also have a newcomer. Joanna is a graphic designer. She's joining us to talk about her impressions as a first time visitor. We'll go through the whole program starting from Monday up to today.
chapters.headline: This is the third time we do this special edition from the visualization conference

chapters.summary: Robert: I've been to the one tutorial, Tamara Munzner's tutorial. The tutorial was mostly about her way of teaching visualization through her fantastic book. This is also the book that I use in my own course. It's a very nice description of the visualization, design space.
chapters.headline: Robert: I've been to one tutorial about visualization from Monday to Thursday

chapters.summary: On Monday, I've also been in the. new symposium of this, that is called visualization in data science. And I do believe that visualization can play a major role there. I'm really looking forward to see how this symposium will develop in the future.
chapters.headline: There is a new symposium about how to use visualization in data science

chapters.summary: Donna Cox is an artist who started working with data visualization in the eighties. She has done a lot of really interesting work in turning data and very simple visualizations into real, into things that people actually want to watch. You have to deliver it to the audience to get them interested, and they managed pretty well.
chapters.headline: On Tuesday, we had the keynote. The keynote was Donna Cox on data visualization

chapters.summary: A paper called probing projections was looking at trying to. project distances down to two or three dimensions. Using multidimensional scaling is one of the ways of doing that. They had some interesting techniques there to show to keep them close together, but still give you a sense of what distances really were.
chapters.headline: Robert: There was a paper about probing projections that I really liked

chapters.summary: One of the papers I want to talk about is called reducing snapshot to points. When you have a network that changes in time, how do you actually visualize that? It's one of those elegant and simple techniques that works surprisingly well.
chapters.gist: Taking a snapshot of a network
chapters.headline: Robert: How do you visualize a network that changes in time

chapters.summary: Robert: Panel on color mapping was really fun. There's a surprising amount of work still to be done in color, even though color research has been around for forever. But especially visualization. It's so specific and so different from general color research that it's just still a very open problem.
chapters.headline: Robert: Panel on color mapping was really good, Robert

chapters.summary: Next, we have another panel. This in the real world. I found Jen Christensen from. the Scientific American. She was talking about how they at the scientific American have to produce visualizations that are aesthetically pleasing, but still have to deliver the scientific background.
chapters.gist: Visualization Design in the Real World
chapters.headline: Panel discussed how companies could need visualization designers for their industrial purposes

chapters.summary: Best paper at Infovis was about human, like, orthogonal network layout. What they were doing is really interesting and kind of obvious as well. It seems like a really nice algorithm, and it's reasonably fast.
chapters.headline: There was a paper at Infovis that got the best paper award

chapters.summary: There was a very interesting paper in the vis session called personal visualization and personal visual analytics. This whole idea of using visualization for personal data is really interesting. There's not a lot of research right now in our community. Shall we move on to Wednesday?
chapters.headline: Last thing I want to talk about from Tuesday is a very interesting paper on personal visualization

chapters.summary: Study looked at how people take notes with Evernote. 70% of the notes taken are never touched ever again. There is quite some potential for visualization to make them more accessible. Some things that came out of that study are somehow included into Evernotes now.
chapters.gist: Personal Visibility at the World Conference
chapters.headline: One paper looked at how people take notes with Evernote

chapters.summary: Qlik Datastories is brought to you by click, who allows you to explore the hidden relationships within your data that lead to meaningful insights. In the post, Marie explains what data literacy is and how we can design visualizations that stretch people's literacy without necessarily shying them away. Thanks again to Qlik for sponsoring us.
chapters.headline: Qlik is a tool that helps designers stretch people's data literacy

chapters.summary: A paper called visually comparing weather features and forecasts. This was work by some folks at University of Utah. They built a system that was based on good decision making. And I think it's actually being used.
chapters.headline: Robert: One paper from Wednesday was visually comparing weather features and forecasts

chapters.summary: Trying to work hand to hand with practitioners has become crucial, I think, to our profession. Sometimes scientists are receptive to suggestions and I've seen them adopting some of the solutions that we suggested.
chapters.gist: Climate science visualization: bridging theory and practice
chapters.headline: The title of this paper is bridging theory with practice. So this is a study we have done

chapters.summary: Well, a related paper in the same session was there matches, mismatches and methods from my group at UBC. What scares me the most about this project is Matthew Bremer, who is the PhD working on that. How does he do that?
chapters.headline: Matthew Bremer did a study with some energy, with an energy company

chapters.summary: A new visualization tool helps poets looking at poetry under different lenses. It's based on translating words into sounds and then using sounds as the input to the visualization. Poets love ambiguity, and exposing ambiguity makes them excited. I think it's very inspiring.
chapters.gist: The Future of Poetry in Visualization
chapters.headline: A group of Mariah Meyer have developed a visualization tool for poets

chapters.summary: The goal of the study is not to understand whether some visualization technique is better than another, but more looking into individual differences and personal traits. And I think they've been looking things like spatial abilities. There are also all sorts of psychological cognitive tests out there that you can run to.
chapters.headline: So next one, perception. Infovis perception. So there was one paper titled spatial reasoning and data displays

chapters.summary: Robert Moorhead attended a panel on solved problems in viz. Some of it was very academic. But there was one really interesting point that Penny Rheingans made. She looked at textbooks and said, well, what are the things you teach in a basic visualization course?
chapters.headline: Robert: Panel on solved problems in viz was interesting

chapters.summary: The panel itself was kind of weird. There wasn't enough going on there. It was an interesting panel because of that, it didn't really lead to real answers. But I think overall it was a good idea.
chapters.headline: Panel on unsolved problems was interesting, but didn't lead to real answers

chapters.summary: SCIVIS, VAST, SCIVIS, VAST and infovis stands for visual analysis, science and technology. I stands for infovis information visualization, which is mostly the visualization of data that's not physically located. And then there are a bunch of workshops and other things that are kind of coming into the fold.
chapters.headline: Can you very quickly describe the difference between SCIVIS, VAST, SCIVIS, VAST and infovis

chapters.summary: A paper in 2012 looked at memorability in visualization. It found that the title makes a huge difference for what people actually remember. When you're doing presentation, it's the whole package. Robert: I think presentation needs to be understood differently.
chapters.headline: Michelle Borkins and colleagues have a paper on memorability in visualization

chapters.summary: Next one, interactive systems. A lot of people don't realize that a visualization is interactive and they don't ever interact with it. The idea is to add things to the visualization to tell you, here you can interact. It's important because you want to teach people more about that.
chapters.headline: Next one, interactive systems. Robert, you wanted to talk about. So there was this paper that I thought was very clever

chapters.summary: Next one, we had another great one about Voyager, new system and Vega. Voyager is built on top of Vega. System automatically suggests charts to you. Makes it easier to explore more of the data.
chapters.gist: Voyager: The System that Suggests Charts
chapters.headline: Next one, we had another great one about Voyager, new system and Vega

chapters.summary: There was another panel this year. Different approaches to teaching visualization. There were lots of questions and ideas about what else to do. It's a common problem in academia that nobody tells you how to teach. There needs to be more exchange of ideas and more support.
chapters.gist: The Next Generation Teaching in Visualization
chapters.headline: Panel discussed different approaches to teaching visualization to general public

chapters.summary: Timeline curator lets you build timelines based on natural language processing. You insert freeform text and the temporal expressions are extracted and displayed on a visual timeline that can then be edited and adjusted. There hasn't been much data journalism applied to data journalism this year. That might change next year again.
chapters.headline: Timeline curator is a tool that automatically generates timelines based on natural language processing

chapters.summary: Robert: One thing that I think we were seeing more of is presentation of data. I think that idea of just more presentation oriented visualization is really interesting and that's going to become more important over time. Joanna: How did you like your first scientific conference?
chapters.headline: One thing that I think we were seeing more of is presentation of data
